question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which institution employed Jose A. Santiago-Saez before 2019?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Title: Unveiling the Tropical Researcher: The Story of Jose A. Santiago-Saez and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute

In the lush, vibrant heart of Panama, a research institute stood as a beacon of scientific discovery, attracting brilliant minds from around the world. The Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) was its name, and unraveling the secrets of the tropical ecosystem was its mission. Among the esteemed researchers who called STRI home was Jose A. Santiago-Saez, a man whose work would leave an indelible mark on the scientific community. As we delve into the narrative of Jose's life, a trail of evidence emerges, weaving a tapestry of facts that unequivocally support the claim: Jose A. Santiago-Saez worked for the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. Our story begins in the early 2000s, when Jose, a young and ambitious researcher, was making a name for himself in the scientific community. His ORCID ID, 0000-0002-6162-5720, would become synonymous with groundbreaking research in the fields of ecology, conservation, and environmental science. As Jose's reputation grew, so did his affiliation with STRI, an institution renowned for its commitment to understanding the complexities of tropical ecosystems. One of the earliest indications of Jose's association with STRI can be found in a 2005 research paper titled "Tropical Forest Fragmentation and Its Impact on Biodiversity." Co-authored with several prominent researchers, including Dr. Egbert Leigh, a renowned ecologist and STRI senior staff scientist, this study demonstrated Jose's involvement with the institute's research initiatives. The paper's acknowledgments section explicitly thanked the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute for its support, providing concrete evidence of Jose's affiliation. Further evidence of Jose's work at STRI can be found in his publication record. A 2008 paper, "Carbon Sequestration in Tropical Forests: A Review of Current Knowledge," listed Jose as a research associate at STRI. This publication not only showcased his expertise in the field but also solidified his connection to the institute. In addition to his research contributions, Jose's involvement with STRI was also reflected in his participation in various scientific conferences and workshops. In 2010, he presented a paper titled "Tropical Forest Ecology and Conservation" at the STRI-organized symposium, "Tropical Ecosystems in a Changing World."
content.source_2: October 2032. The crisp autumn air whispered through the streets of Philadelphia, carrying the whispers of innovation and discovery. In the heart of the city, the University of Pennsylvania hummed with activity, its esteemed researchers pushing the boundaries of human knowledge. Among them was Dr. Jose A. Santiago-Saez, a brilliant mind with a passion for unraveling the mysteries of the universe. His ORCID ID, 0000-0002-6162-5720, was a badge of honor, a testament to his contributions to the scientific community. As the leaves turned golden, Dr. Santiago-Saez delved deeper into his latest project, fueled by the university's cutting-edge resources and his own insatiable curiosity. His days blended together in a blur of lab work, data analysis, and collaboration with his colleagues. On a typical morning, Dr. Santiago-Saez would arrive at the university's state-of-the-art research facility, the soft glow of the LED lights illuminating his path. He'd exchange nods and greetings with his peers, the air thick with the aroma of freshly brewed coffee and the soft hum of machinery. As the weeks went by, Dr. Santiago-Saez's research began to take shape. He poured over lines of code, pouring his heart and soul into the project. The university's advanced computing systems whirred to life, processing vast amounts of data as Dr. Santiago-Saez worked tirelessly to unlock the secrets of his research. October 15, 2032, marked a pivotal moment in Dr. Santiago-Saez's journey. It was on this day that he made a groundbreaking discovery, one that would send ripples throughout the scientific community. The university's corridors buzzed with excitement as news of his findings spread, drawing in colleagues from various departments to discuss the implications. As the month drew to a close, Dr. Santiago-Saez's work was met with international acclaim. The University of Pennsylvania's reputation as a hub of innovation was solidified, and Dr. Santiago-Saez's name became synonymous with excellence in his field. In the midst of this whirlwind, Dr. Santiago-Saez remained humble, his focus fixed on the next challenge, the next mystery to unravel. As the seasons changed, and the year drew to a close, he stood at the forefront of a new era in scientific discovery, his work a testament to the power of human ingenuity.
